178 S.E.2d 65 (1970)

STATE of North Carolina
v.
O'Neal REAMS.
No. 43.
Supreme Court of North Carolina.
December 16, 1970.
*67 Atty. Gen. Robert Morgan and Staff Atty. James L. Blackburn, Raleigh, for the State.
Charles Darsie and W. G. Pearson, II, Durham, for defendant.
BRANCH, Justice.
Defendant assigns as error the denial of his motion to suppress evidence relating to the shotgun that his wife delivered to police officers. He contends that this evidence was obtained by an unreasonable search of his home in violation of the constitutional rights secured to him by the Fourth and Fifth Amendments to the United States Constitution and by Article I, Section 15 of the North Carolina Constitution, and he asserts that his wife could not waive his constitutional rights by consenting to a search of their home.
It is well settled, in both federal and state courts, that evidence obtained by unreasonable search and seizure is inadmissible. Fourth and Fifth Amendments to the United States Constitution; Article I, Section 15, North Carolina Constitution; G.S. § 15-27; Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, 81 S. Ct. 1684, 6 L. Ed. 2d 1081; State v. Colson, 274 N.C. 295, 163 S.E.2d 376. However, the constitutional protection claimed *68 by defendant does not extend to all searches and seizures, but only to those which are unreasonable.
